events.title: Drought in Turkiye (Turkey) - Winter 2022-2023
events.description: Severe lack of precipitation affecting Turkiye with impacts on soil moisture and river flows. December 2022 was characterized as the hottest in the last 52 years for Central Turkey. Negative precipitation anomalies detected across most of the country.

impacts.description: Sowing dates delayed by approximately one month in Central Turkey due to dry soil conditions
Crop season hampered in southeastern regions due to winter drought
Reservoirs below 50% filling level as of mid-February 2023
Reduced snow accumulation due to warm winter raising concerns for future runoff and infiltration
Limited crop water demand in winter but expected increase in spring requiring irrigation

atmosphericConditions.pattern: Strong anomalous cyclonic circulation west of Iberian Peninsula combined with anomalous anticyclonic circulation over eastern Mediterranean
atmosphericConditions.effect: Induced southerly wind anomalies affecting the region

relatedEvents.earthquakes: The February 2023 catastrophic earthquakes in the Turkey-Syria border region caused damages to dams and river infrastructures, complicating the drought situation
relatedEvents.warmSpell: Mid-December 2022 experienced a prolonged warm-spell affecting the Maghreb and partially Turkey

historicalContext.droughtHistory: Turkey has experienced significant droughts in 1973, 1974, 1983, 1989, 1990, 1996, 2001, 2007, 2008, 2013-2014, and 2020-2021
historicalContext.waterStress: Turkey is classified as a water stressed country
historicalContext.vulnerableRegions: Central Anatolia (Konya Basin) is the most vulnerable region with annual precipitation below 400mm
